query: Tell me a bio of D. B. Nihalsinghe.
answer:
Dr. Diongu Badaturuge Nihalsinghe, known as D. B. Nihalsinghe (27 May 1939 – 21 April 2016), was a renowned Sri Lankan film director, cinematographer, editor, and producer. Nihalsinghe was celebrated for his versatility and pioneering contributions to Sri Lankan film and television. He introduced professional television production to Sri Lanka in 1979, marking a significant milestone in the country's media landscape. His career began with his role as a cameraman and editor for the film "Sath Samudura," where his fluid camera work, influenced by his newsreel experience, was widely recognized as innovative.

Nihalsinghe's notable works include the groundbreaking film "Welikada" and the teledrama "Dimuthu Muthu," the first television drama series in South Asia. He received the Cardiff Commonwealth Film Festival award for his first film "Bakhti." His film "Ridi Nimnaya" (1983) and "Kelimadala" were also highly acclaimed, with the latter winning the highest number of national awards at that time. Nihalsinghe was honored with the Sri Lankan national award "KalaKeerthi" for his lifetime contributions to film and television. query: Tell me a bio of Zelma Wilson.
answer: Zelma Wilson (November 23, 1918 – May 10, 1996) was an American architect who practiced primarily in California. Born in New York City to Russian Jewish immigrants, she was raised in Santa Paula, California, by her mother Rose and stepfather Ed Kraus. Wilson graduated from Santa Paula Union High School and majored in art at the University of California, Berkeley. She earned her architecture license in 1957 and worked with notable architects such as Richard Neutra, Victor Gruen, Rudolph Schindler, and Raphael Soriano. In 1964, she and her family returned to California and settled in Ojai, where she opened her own architectural firm. Wilson served as president of the Ventura County branch of the American Institute of Architects (AIA) in 1977 and was named a Fellow of the AIA in 1983. She received the City of Ojai's "Lifetime Achievement in the Arts Award" in 1994. Wilson was also active in earthquake preparedness and lectured on architecture at Cal Poly San Luis Obispo. She was widowed in 1978 when her husband, screenwriter Michael Wilson, died. She was presented with his posthumous Academy Award in 1985 and appeared in the 1987 documentary "Legacy of the Hollywood Blacklist."

query: Tell me a bio of Adnan Sami.
answer:
Adnan Sami Khan, born on 15 August 1971 in London, is a renowned singer, musician, music composer, pianist, and actor. His father, Arshad Sami Khan, was a Pakistani diplomat of Pashtun origin, and his mother, Naureen, was from Jammu and Kashmir. Sami was raised and educated in the United Kingdom and can play over 35 musical instruments. He is credited for being the first person to play Indian classical music on the piano in a style he created through the Santoor. His first single, "Run for His Life," was released in 1986, and he was described by US-based "Keyboard" magazine as the fastest keyboard player in the world and the keyboard discovery of the 90s.

Sami's career highlights include winning the Nigar Award, Bolan Academy Award, and Graduate Award. He is the youngest recipient of the Naushad Music Award for Excellence in Music. In 2001, he was awarded the Breakthrough Artist of the Year by MTV. He has performed at prestigious music festivals and sold-out stadiums in over 40 countries, including two consecutive nights at Wembley Stadium in London in 2003. Sami has composed and sung for Hindi films, collaborating with top producers like Yash Chopra and Subhash Ghai. His notable works include the film "Sargam," which was a box office

query: Tell me a bio of Ivan Perišić.
answer: Ivan Perišić (born 2 February 1989) is a Croatian professional footballer who plays as a winger, attacking midfielder, or second striker. A product of the Hajduk Split and Sochaux youth academies, Perišić made a significant impact at Club Brugge, where he was the Belgian Pro League top goalscorer and named Belgian Footballer of the Year in 2011. He joined Inter Milan in 2015 on a five-year contract for a transfer fee of €16 million, where he has been a key player, scoring his first Serie A hat-trick in a 5–0 win over Chievo in 2017. Perišić has also been a vital member of the Croatia national team, making his debut in 2011 and participating in major tournaments such as UEFA Euro 2012 and the 2014 and 2018 FIFA World Cups. During the 2018 World Cup qualifying campaign, he scored the third goal in a 4–1 win against Greece, helping Croatia secure their spot in the final stages. His contributions to both club and country have solidified his reputation as one of Croatia's top football talents.

query: Tell me a bio of David Bogue.
answer: David Bogue (18 February 1750 – 25 October 1825) was a British nonconformist leader. Born in the parish of Coldingham, Berwickshire, Scotland, Bogue pursued his education in Edinburgh and was licensed to preach by the Church of Scotland. However, he moved to London in 1771 to teach in schools at Edmonton, Hampstead, and Camberwell. In 1777, he settled as the minister of the Congregational church at Gosport in Hampshire, where his predecessors had established a strong foundation. Bogue's contributions to the Congregational church and his leadership in nonconformist circles were significant, though specific details of his major achievements and notable works are not provided in the available documents. His career and life were marked by his dedication to religious and educational pursuits, making him a respected figure in the nonconformist community of his time.

query: Tell me a bio of Egon Krenz.
answer: Egon Rudi Ernst Krenz, born on 19 March 1937, is a former East German politician who served as the last communist leader of East Germany during the final months of 1989. He joined the Free German Youth (FDJ) in 1953 and the Socialist Unity Party of Germany (SED) in 1955. After serving in the Volksarmee from 1959 to 1961, he studied at a prestigious Communist Party staff school in Moscow, obtaining a social science degree by 1967. Krenz held various prominent positions in the SED, including Honecker's deputy from 1984 onward. He succeeded Honecker as General Secretary of the SED in 1989 but was forced to resign amid the fall of the Berlin Wall. In 1997, Krenz was sentenced to six-and-a-half years in prison for Cold War crimes, including manslaughter of Germans attempting to escape over the Berlin Wall. He was released in December 2003 and retired to Dierhagen in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern. Unlike other former SED members, Krenz continues to defend the old East Germany and maintains his political views.

query: Tell me a bio of Abdou Diallo.
answer:
Abdou Diallo (born 4 May 1996) is a French professional footballer who plays as a defender for Borussia Dortmund. Born in Tours, Diallo joined the youth academy of AS Monaco FC at the age of 15. On 28 March 2014, he signed his first professional contract with the club, and Vice-president Vadim Vasilyev praised his talent and potential. Diallo is of Senegalese descent and has captained France's U-21 team. He is the older brother of footballer Ibrahima Diallo. 

Diallo's professional career includes a significant move to Borussia Dortmund, where he signed a five-year contract on 26 June 2018. On 9 September 2018, he scored his first goal for Dortmund in a 3–1 league victory against Bayer 04 Leverkusen. During his time at Dortmund, he has been deployed in both back three and back four formations, showcasing his versatility and strong defensive skills. Rouven Schröder, the sporting director of 1. FSV Mainz, has described Diallo as "strong in the air and shrewd in the challenge."

query: Tell me a bio of Kelli White.
answer: Kelli White (born April 1, 1977, in Oakland, California) is an American former sprinter. She achieved significant success in her career, notably winning two gold medals at the World Championships in Paris in 2003. However, her achievements were marred when she tested positive for performance-enhancing drugs, including tetrahydrogestrinone (THG) and erythropoietin (EPO), leading to the stripping of her medals on June 18, 2004. White was subsequently banned from competition for two years by the United States Anti-Doping Agency, effective May 17, 2004. Her doping was linked to the BALCO doping scandal, and she admitted to using the substances provided by BALCO head Victor Conte, who initially presented them as supplements and vitamins. After her ban, White retired from professional track in May 2006. Despite her fall from grace, she has since worked to educate others about the dangers of drug abuse in sports, becoming the first athlete to collaborate directly with the United States Anti-Doping Agency to help understand the culture of doping at the elite level. She has also taught at track clinics at James Logan High School.

query: Tell me a bio of Luis N. Rivera-Pagán.
answer: Luis Nicolás Rivera-Pagán (born December 5, 1942 in San Juan, Puerto Rico) is a distinguished theologian and academic. He earned his M.Div. from the Evangelical Seminary of Puerto Rico in 1966, followed by an S.T.M. (1967) and M.A. (1968) from Yale University, and a Ph.D. from Yale in 1970. Between 1970 and 2003, Rivera-Pagán served as a Professor of Systematic Theology at the Evangelical Seminary of Puerto Rico and as a Professor of Humanities at the University of Puerto Rico. He was appointed the John Alexander Mackay Visiting Professor on World Christianity at Princeton Theological Seminary during his sabbatical year from 1999 to 2000, which led to his appointment as the Henry Winters Luce Professor of Ecumenics at Princeton Theological Seminary in 2003. Rivera-Pagán is a prolific author, having written, co-authored, edited, and co-edited numerous books, journal issues, chapters, and articles. His contributions to theological and academic discourse are widely recognized, and he continues to hold the position of Henry Winters Luce Professor Emeritus at Princeton Theological Seminary.

query: Tell me a bio of Anurag Kashyap.
answer: Anurag Kashyap (born 10 September 1972) is an Indian film director, writer, editor, producer, and actor known for his works in Hindi cinema. He is the recipient of several accolades, including a National Film Award and four Filmfare Awards. Kashyap's career began with writing a television serial, and he gained significant recognition for his directorial debut with "Black Friday" (2007), a film based on the 1993 Bombay bombings. His subsequent films, such as "Dev D" (2009) and "That Girl in Yellow Boots" (2011), received critical acclaim and were screened at various international film festivals. In 2013, he was awarded the Ordre des Arts et des Lettres (Knight of the Order of Arts and Letters) by the French government at the Cannes Film Festival. Kashyap has also served as a jury member at several film festivals and is a member of the board of the NGO Aangan, which helps protect vulnerable children in India. Notable works include "Gulaal" (2009), "Ugly" (2013), "Raman Raghav 2.0" (2016), and "Sacred Games" (2018), the latter being India's first Netflix Original series. His films often employ guerrilla-filmmaking techniques and real locations

query: Tell me a bio of Fahadh Faasil.
answer: Fahadh Faasil is an Indian film actor and producer, primarily working in the Malayalam film industry. He made his debut at the age of 19 in his father Fazil's 2002 romantic film "Kaiyethum Doorath," which, despite his father's renowned status, was a critical and commercial failure. After a six-year hiatus, Fahadh returned to the screen with the anthology film "Kerala Cafe" (2009), where he starred in the short film "Mrityunjayam." His breakthrough came with the role of Arjun, which garnered significant public attention. Fahadh's career took a significant turn with his performances in "Artist" and "North 24 Kaatham," for which he won the National Film Award for Best Actor and the Filmfare Award for Best Actor. He further solidified his status with roles in "Bangalore Days" (2014) and "Iyobinte Pustakam," the latter of which he also produced. In 2016, his performance in "Maheshinte Prathikaaram" became a blockbuster, and he won the National Film Award for Best Supporting Actor for his role in "Thondimuthalum Driksakshiyum" (2017). Fahadh is married to actress Nazriya Nazim, whom he met on the sets of "Bangalore Days." They got engaged in January

query: Tell me a bio of Gerardo Fernandez Fe.
answer:
Gerardo Fernandez Fe (born January 15, 1971, in Havana, Cuba) is a renowned Cuban novelist and essayist. He graduated from the University of Havana in 1995 with a degree in French Language. Fernandez Fe has worked as a translator and professor of French in Cuba and Ecuador. His literary career began with his first book of poetry, "El llanto del escriba," which won the Luis Rogelias Nogueras poetry prize in Havana and was published in 1997. This was followed by "Relicarios" (1994) and "Las palabras pedestres" (1996), the latter of which won the David prize of poetry in 1995. His first novella, "La Falacia," published in 1999, received critical acclaim, with Cuban writer Leonardo Padura describing it as a work of "deep anxiety and odd maturity."

Fernandez Fe's notable works include the novels "La Falacia" (1999) and "El último día del estornino" (2011), and the essay collections "Cuerpo a diario" (2007) and "Notas al total" (2015). Jimmy Bartel, full name Jimmy James Ross Bartel, is a former Australian rules footballer who played for the Geelong Football Club in the Australian Football League (AFL). Born on December 4, 1983, Bartel is a versatile player capable of contributing as a midfielder, forward, or defender. He made his AFL debut in 2002 and quickly established himself as a key player, earning numerous accolades and achievements throughout his career. Bartel is a triple premiership player, having won the AFL Grand Final in 2007, 2009, and 2011. He was awarded the Brownlow Medal in 2008 and the Norm Smith Medal in 2009. Additionally, he was selected for the All-Australian team twice.

Bartel's career was marked by consistent performances and significant milestones. He played his 200th game in 2011 and his 300th game in 2016. Notably, he had a career-high 41 possessions in a game against North Melbourne in 2015 and equaled this record in 2016 against Melbourne. query: Tell me a bio of Daniil Medvedev.
answer: Daniil Sergeyevich Medvedev (born 11 February 1996) is a Russian tennis player. He has achieved significant success in his career, including winning 3 ATP singles titles. Medvedev reached his career-high ATP singles ranking of 16 on 5 November 2018 and his highest ATP doubles ranking of 265 on 18 September 2017. His professional tennis career began with his ATP main draw debut at the 2015 Kremlin Cup, where he partnered Aslan Karatsev in the doubles event. As a qualifier, Medvedev made his ATP singles main draw debut at the 2016 St. Petersburg Open. His rapid rise in the tennis world has marked him as a prominent figure in Russian tennis.

query: Tell me a bio of Gary Woodland.
answer:
Gary Woodland (born May 21, 1984) is an American professional golfer who plays on the PGA Tour. Born in Topeka, Kansas, to Dan and Linda Woodland, he attended Shawnee Heights High School in Tecumseh. After a brief stint on a basketball scholarship at Washburn University, Woodland transferred to the University of Kansas on a golf scholarship, where he studied Sociology.

Woodland's professional career began with challenges. He struggled in his debut PGA Tour season in 2009, making only eight cuts in 18 appearances before a shoulder injury cut his season short. However, he persevered, and in 2011, he won the Omega Mission Hills World Cup with Matt Kuchar. His breakthrough came in 2011 when he won the Transitions Championship by one stroke, securing a place at the 2011 Masters Tournament and elevating him to 53rd in the Official World Golf Rankings. In 2018, Woodland won the Waste Management Phoenix Open in a sudden-death playoff, ending a five-year drought on tour. He also held the 36-hole lead at the 2018 PGA Championship, finishing tied for sixth. Woodland's career highlights include reaching the final of the 2015 WGC-Cadillac Match Play, where he lost to Rory McIlroy, and moving to a career-best 32

   - Gary Woodland qualified for the PGA Tour in 2009.

   - He ended his first season on the PGA Tour after learning he had a torn labrum in his left shoulder.
   - He last competed in July 2009 at the U.S. Bank Championship in Milwaukee.
   - On August 12, 2009, he underwent surgery to repair a torn labrum in his left shoulder.
   - He began rehab the next day.

   - He withdrew from the Canadian Open and had season-ending surgery on his left shoulder.
   - An inflammation of the rotator cuff in his left shoulder forced him to cut his season short by nine weeks.

- The inflammation in his left shoulder, specifically the rotator cuff, caused him to withdraw from the Canadian Open.
- He underwent surgery to repair a torn labrum in his left shoulder on August 12, 2009.
- He had to cut his season short by nine weeks due to the inflammation and subsequent surgery.
- These points strongly support the statement that a shoulder injury cut Gary Woodland's 2009 PGA Tour season short.

### Conclusion:
The statement "A shoulder injury cut Gary Woodland's 2009 PGA Tour season short" is supported by the provided knowledge. The inflammation and subsequent surgery on his left shoulder in 2009 led to him cutting his season short by nine weeks.

query: Tell me a bio of Worranit Thawornwong.
answer: Worranit Thawornwong, better known as Mook (มุก), is a Thai actress and singer born on October 9, 1996, in Bangkok, Thailand. She is the second child in her family, and her brother, Jirakit Thawornwong, is also an actor. Worranit attended high school at Satriwitthaya 2 School and later studied at Kasetsart University. She gained significant popularity for her role as Junior in the 2015 Thai television series "Ugly Duckling Series: Perfect Match," where she was paired with Puttichai Kasetsin. In addition to acting, she sang a song for the series, further enhancing her multifaceted talent. Following her success in "Ugly Duckling," Worranit participated in the drama "Kiss The Series" in 2016, where she was paired with Sattaphong Phiangphor. She is also set to appear in the series "U-Prince," specifically in the segment titled "Ambitious Boss," where she will be paired with March Chutavuth Pattarakampol. Her other notable works include roles in "Mah Tun Welah Por Dee," "Kon Jao Choo" (also known as "Bee Dup Bee Doo"), and "Poot Wah Ruk Nai Jai" for "Roon Pee Secret Love."

query: Tell me a bio of Aaron Burr.
answer:
Aaron Burr Jr. (February 6, 1756 – September 14, 1836) was an American politician and lawyer. He served as the third Vice President of the United States from 1801 to 1805 during Thomas Jefferson's first term. Burr's political career included serving in the New York State Assembly (1784–1785, 1798–1799) and as New York State Attorney General (1789–1791). He was also a Commissioner of Revolutionary War Claims in 1791 and a U.S. Senator from New York (1791–1797). Burr ran for president in the 1796 election, placing fourth, and again in 1800, where he and Jefferson tied in the electoral vote, leading to a contentious election resolved by the House of Representatives.

Burr's most notorious actions include his 1804 duel with Alexander Hamilton, which resulted in Hamilton's death, and his 1807 arrest and trial for treason, from which he was ultimately acquitted. He was the son of Aaron Burr Sr., a founder of the College of New Jersey (now Princeton University), and his mother, Esther Edwards Burr, was the daughter of Jonathan Edwards. query: Tell me a bio of Richard Burkewood Welbourn.
answer: Richard Burkewood Welbourn, FRCS (1 May 1919 in Rainhill, Lancashire – 3 August 2005 in Reading, Berkshire), was a British scientist and educator specializing in surgical endocrinology. He attended Rugby School, Emmanuel College, Cambridge, and Liverpool University, graduating in 1942. After his education, Welbourn earned a Fulbright scholarship to the Mayo Clinic. In 1952, he joined the staff of Queen's University, Belfast (QUB), and in 1958, he was appointed Professor of Surgical Science. In 1962, he moved to the Royal Postgraduate Medical School at Hammersmith Hospital, where he gained recognition for his work on phaeochromocytoma. Welbourn served as Professor and Chairman of the Department of Surgery at the Royal Postgraduate Medical School, making significant contributions to the field of surgical endocrinology. His career was marked by his dedication to research and education, and he is remembered for his influential work in advancing surgical science.

query: Tell me a bio of Idi Amin.
answer: Idi Amin Dada Oumee was a Ugandan politician and military officer who served as the President of Uganda from 1971 to 1979. Born to a Kakwa father and a Lugbara mother, either in Koboko or Kampala around 1925, Amin joined the King's African Rifles (KAR) of the British Colonial Army in 1946. He rose through the ranks, initially serving as a cook before becoming a lieutenant and participating in British military actions. Amin's rule was marked by severe human rights abuses, political repression, and economic mismanagement. He expelled Ugandan Asians and nationalized British-owned businesses, leading to strained international relations, particularly with India, the UK, and Israel. In 1972, he broke diplomatic ties with the UK and Israel, turning to Muammar Gaddafi and the Soviet Union for support. Amin's regime was characterized by widespread violence and is estimated to have resulted in the deaths of between 100,000 and 500,000 people. In 1978, after attempting to annex Tanzania's Kagera Region, Amin faced a joint Ugandan-Tanzanian invasion that led to his overthrow in 1979. He went into exile, first in Libya and then in Saudi Arabia, where he died on 16 August 2003. Despite his brutal

query: Tell me a bio of Heinrich Himmler.
answer: Heinrich Luitpold Himmler was born on 7 October 1900 in Munich, Germany, into a conservative middle-class Roman Catholic family. His father, Joseph Gebhard Himmler, was a teacher, and his mother, Anna Maria Himmler (née Heyder), was a devout Roman Catholic. Heinrich had two brothers, Gebhard Ludwig and Ernst Hermann. Himmler rose to prominence within the Nazi Party, becoming the "Reichsführer-SS" and one of the most powerful figures under Adolf Hitler. Historians note his pedantic, dogmatic, and shrewd nature, which contributed to his significant influence. By 1933, the SS, under his leadership, had grown to 52,000 members, with strict membership requirements ensuring all members were of Hitler's Aryan "Herrenvolk." Himmler's role in the Nazi regime was pivotal, and he was second in actual power to Hitler. On 23 May 1945, Himmler was captured by British forces and taken to the headquarters of the Second British Army in Lüneburg. During a medical examination, he bit into a hidden potassium cyanide pill and died within 15 minutes. His body was subsequently buried in an unmarked grave near Lüneburg, the location of which remains unknown.

query: Tell me a bio of William G. Angel.
answer: William Gardner Angel (July 17, 1790 – August 13, 1858) was an American politician and lawyer. Born in New Shoreham, Rhode Island, he moved with his parents to a farm in Richfield, New York, in 1792. He attended common schools and worked on the family farm. In 1809, Angel was hired by William Dowse, a lawyer from Cooperstown, as a handyman and began reading law in Dowse's office. He married Emily P. English in 1812, and they had several children, including William P. Angel and Wilkes Angel. Angel practiced law in partnership with his son Wilkes from 1843 to 1847. He served as a delegate to the New York State Constitutional Convention of 1846 and as First Judge and Surrogate of the Allegany County Court from 1847 to 1851. Angel died on August 13, 1858, in Angelica, Allegany County, New York, and was buried at the Until the Day Dawn Cemetery.

query: Tell me a bio of Lina Marulanda.
answer:
Lina María Marulanda Cuartas (15 May 1980 – 22 April 2010) was a Colombian television personality and model. Born in Medellín, Colombia, Marulanda began her modeling career at the age of 12. She attended Santa María del Rosario de Medellín High School initially but later transferred to Parra Paris High School, from which she graduated after conflicts with the directors and nuns at her first school. Marulanda pursued higher education at Tadeo Lozano University in Bogota, where she studied advertising.

Marulanda's career in media began in 2002 when she debuted as a presenter at CM& News. She later joined Caracol News, where she presented the 0700 edition and the international section of the broadcast for six years. From 2003, she also hosted the entertainment portion of the evening news, initially alongside actress Margarita Ortega and later with model Adriana Arboleda. In December 2005, she transitioned to the entertainment segment of Caracol News. In 2007, Marulanda returned to CM& News to cover special reports on Colombiamoda and joined W Radio's "La hora del Regreso," replacing Marcela Sarmiento. She was a spokesmodel for major clothing brands and appeared in magazines such as "SoHo," "Don Juan,"

query: Tell me a bio of Nancy Onyango.
answer:
Nancy Asiko Onyango, commonly known as Nancy Onyango, is a Kenyan accountant, businesswoman, and corporate executive. She currently serves as the Director of the Office of Internal Audit and Inspection at the International Monetary Fund (IMF), a position she has held since February 2018. Prior to her appointment at the IMF, Onyango was the CEO of Reliance Risk Advisory Solutions, a Nairobi-based consultancy firm. She has also held significant roles at PwC, where she was a Partner leading the consulting unit at PwC East Africa from July 2005 to June 2012, and later as the head of the Risk Assurance Services Unit from July 2012 to October 2014. 

Onyango's expertise in technology, governance, risk, and compliance has been recognized through various board appointments. She serves as a Non-executive director of Kenya Commercial Bank Group and Cytonn Investments, and she chairs the audit and finance committee of Fairtrade Africa. Her career has been marked by a strong focus on risk management and corporate governance, contributing significantly to the financial and regulatory landscape in Kenya and beyond.

query: Tell me a bio of Carol Dweck.
answer:
Carol S. Dweck, born on October 17, 1946, in New York, is the Lewis and Virginia Eaton Professor of Psychology at Stanford University. Dweck's research focuses on motivation, personality, and development, with a significant emphasis on implicit theories of intelligence. Her groundbreaking work is encapsulated in her 2006 book, "Mindset: The New Psychology of Success," which introduces the concept of growth and fixed mindsets. According to Dweck, individuals with a growth mindset believe their abilities can be developed through dedication and hard work, while those with a fixed mindset believe their abilities are static and unchangeable.

Dweck has held teaching positions at Columbia University, Harvard University, and the University of Illinois before joining Stanford University in 2004. Her research has been widely recognized, earning her the Distinguished Scientific Contribution Award from the American Psychological Association in 2011 and the Yidan Prize for Education Research in 2017, which included a $3.8 million award to support her ongoing work. Dweck's theories have been influential in educational interventions, particularly in fostering resilience and motivation among students. She continues to teach courses in Developmental Psychology and Self Theories at Stanford, aiming to empower individuals to achieve greater personal freedom and equality.

claims.claim: Carol Dweck aims to empower individuals to achieve greater personal freedom and equality through her teaching.
claims.label: Supported

safe_raw.response:
### Step-by-Step Reasoning

1. **Summarize the Main Points of the KNOWLEDGE:**
   - **Goal of Dweck's Work:** Carol Dweck's ultimate goal is to reduce stress and encourage people to persevere when faced with challenges.
   - **Fixed vs. Growth Mindset:** Individuals with a fixed mindset tend to stay down when they face setbacks, whereas a growth mindset promotes resilience and perseverance.
   - **Research Focus:** Dweck and her colleagues have conducted extensive research on the impact of mindsets on motivation, self-regulation, and achievement, particularly in ethnically and economically diverse student populations.
   - **Program Development:** Dweck has developed programs to help parents and teachers encourage children to adopt a growth mindset.
   - **Motivation and Self-Regulation:** Dweck is interested in how mindset influences motivation and self-regulation.
   - **Practical Applications:** Her theory is applied in various settings to foster a growth mindset culture and unlock potential.

2. **Evaluate the STATEMENT:**
   - **Personal Freedom and Equality:** The statement suggests that Dweck aims to empower individuals to achieve greater personal freedom and equality through her teaching.
   - **Supporting Evidence:**
     - **Reduce Stress and Encourage Perseverance:** Dweck's goal to reduce stress and encourage perseverance is a form of empowerment, as it helps individuals overcome challenges and maintain their well-being.
     - **Impact on Achievement:** Her research shows that a growth mindset can lead to better academic and personal achievement, which can contribute to personal freedom.
     - **Diverse Populations:** The fact that her research includes ethnically and economically diverse students suggests a commitment to equality, as her work aims to help a wide range of individuals.
     - **Program Development:** The programs she has developed to encourage a growth mindset in children can be seen as a way to empower them and promote equal opportunities for success.

3. **Conclusion:**
   - The statement is supported by the knowledge provided. Dweck's work on fostering a growth mindset, reducing stress, and encouraging perseverance aligns with the goal of empowering individuals. Her research and programs, which target diverse populations, also suggest a commitment to promoting equality.

### Final Answer
[Supported]

query: Tell me a bio of Carlos Ghosn.
answer: Carlos Ghosn, KBE (born March 9, 1954), is a Brazilian-born businessman with French and Lebanese nationality. Ghosn has held several high-profile positions in the automotive industry, including CEO of Michelin North America, chairman and CEO of Renault, chairman of AvtoVAZ, chairman and former CEO of Nissan, and chairman of Mitsubishi Motors. He was also the chairman and CEO of the Renault–Nissan–Mitsubishi Alliance, a strategic partnership between these automotive manufacturers. Ghosn's career is marked by significant achievements, such as his successful restructuring of Renault and Nissan, which earned him celebrity status in Japan and the business world. He was named a "Super Leader" in 2004 and 2005 and was the subject of a Japanese manga comic book. In 2016, Nissan acquired a controlling stake in Mitsubishi Motors, and Ghosn took on the role of chairman to rehabilitate the company. However, his career took a dramatic turn in 2018 when he was arrested for under-reporting his earnings and misuse of company assets, leading to his dismissal as Nissan's chairman. Ghosn has also been recognized for his contributions to the business community through various awards and honors.

query: Tell me a bio of Mohamed Abdi Mohamed.
answer:
Mohamed Abdi Mohamed, also known as "Gandhi," is a prominent Somali geologist, anthropologist, historian, and politician. Born and raised in Somalia, Mohamed excelled academically from a young age, memorizing the Koran at an early stage. He pursued higher education in France, where he returned to Somalia annually to teach and support as a professor. His academic contributions include the publication of scientific articles and the editing of three studies.

Mohamed has held several high-ranking positions in the Somali government. He served as the Minister of Defense and as the President of Azania (Jubaland). In 2011, he was elected President of Azania States. Additionally, he has been a Member of Parliament of the Transitional Federal Government (TFG) and a senior program advisor for the UNDP Somalia in Disarmament, Demobilization, and Reintegration (DDR). An active participant in the Somali peace process, he chaired the Technical Committee at the Arta Somali Peace process and was a member of the Somali Civil Society at the Somali Peace and Reconciliation Conference.

In July 2014, Mohamed was appointed as Somalia's Ambassador to Canada, marking the reopening of the Somali federal government's embassy in Ottawa after more than two decades. His appointment highlights his significant role in international diplomacy and his commitment to advancing Somalia's interests on the global stage.

query: Tell me a bio of Wahida Prism Khan.
answer: Wahida Prism Khan is an Indian naval surgeon and a pioneering figure in the Indian Navy. Born in 1972 in Thanamandi, Rajouri, to Gulzar Ahmed and Hajara Kaser, both teachers, Khan is one of five siblings. Her elder sister, Jubin, serves as Deputy Superintendent in the J&K Police. Khan's father was tragically killed by unidentified militants in 2001. Despite this, Khan pursued her education, completing her schooling in Thanamandi and her intermediate from the Government Girls School in Rajouri. She earned her MBBS from the Government Medical College in Jammu. In 1997, she completed an orientation training course at the Officer's Training School in Lucknow and was commissioned into the Navy. Khan made history in 2006 by becoming the first woman to command the annual parade at the Armed Forces Medical College in Pune. She is also the first woman from Jammu & Kashmir to join the Indian Navy. Khan has served aboard the naval ship INS Amba for 19 months and aims to become the first woman to work in submarines. Her career is marked by her dedication to serving in the armed forces, a desire inspired by her late father.

query: Tell me a bio of Sian Massey-Ellis.
answer:
Sian Louise Massey-Ellis, born on 5 October 1985, is an English football match official based in Coventry. She primarily officiates as an assistant referee in the Premier League and the Football League. Massey-Ellis turned professional in March 2010 and was appointed to the FIFA list of women assistant referees the same year. Her career highlights include officiating in the Football League Trophy, UEFA Women's Champions League, and FIFA Women's World Cup qualification rounds. In August 2011, she was appointed to the Select Group of match officials, a recognition of her high standards and performance.

Massey-Ellis made her Premier League debut as an assistant referee on 28 December 2010, during Blackpool's 2–0 away win at Sunderland. She has also been involved in significant matches, including Liverpool's 3–0 win at Wolverhampton Wanderers on 22 January 2011, which sparked a sexism controversy over remarks made by Premier League broadcaster Sky Sports staff. In 2017, she was appointed Member of the Order of the British Empire (MBE) for her services to football. Her international career includes roles as an assistant referee in the 2007 FIFA Women's World Cup qualification matches and the 2011 UEFA Women's European Championship. She is married to Robert Ellis, who is also a football referee.

answer: Marcus Aurelius, known as the Philosopher, was a Roman emperor who ruled from 161 AD until his death on 17 March 180 AD. Born on 26 April 121 AD in Rome, his birth name was Marcus Annius Verus, though he was later known as Marcus Annius Catilius Severus or Marcus Catilius Severus Annius Verus. He was born into a patrician family, with his father, Marcus Annius Verus III, being the grandson of a Roman senator, and his mother, Domitia Lucilla, a wealthy heiress. After his father's death, he was adopted by Antoninus Pius in 138 AD, who succeeded Emperor Hadrian later that year. Marcus Aurelius was educated at home, with tutors including the grammarian Marcus Cornelius Fronto and the Stoic philosopher Apollonius of Chalcedon, who had a profound influence on his philosophical development. He married Antoninus Pius' daughter, Faustina, and served as Roman consul three times before his accession. Marcus Aurelius is renowned for his philosophical work, "Meditations," a series of personal writings that reflect his Stoic philosophy and provide insights into his thoughts and principles. He ruled the Roman Empire with his adoptive brother, Lucius Verus, until Lucius' death in 169 AD. Marcus Aurelius is considered the

query: Tell me a bio of Dominic King.
answer: Dominic King (born 1974 in Dover, Kent) is a British radio broadcaster and journalist. He began his career as a journalist with the "Early Times" newspaper for young people and later worked as a youth reporter on the BBC Nature series, presented by Michael Buerk. King has worked for several commercial radio stations in the south east of England, including KFM in Tonbridge, Mercury FM in Crawley, and BBC Surrey. He joined the new BBC South East news division in Tunbridge Wells in 2001, initially as a news reader for BBC Radio Kent, before becoming the regular drive presenter with his "Big Drive Home" show. In January 2008, he took over the mid-morning slot, titled "Dominic King in the Morning," and in July 2009, he returned to the 4-7 pm drivetime programme. King has won two Gold BBC Frank Gillard awards for local radio and a Gold Sony Radio Academy Award for his coverage of the 60th anniversary of the D-Day landings in Normandy. He is married and lives on the Romney Marsh with his two dogs, Toby and Smudge. Additionally, he is a crew member of the Littlestone RNLI.

query: Tell me a bio of Karni Liddell.
answer: Karni Liddell (born 1 March 1979) is an Australian Paralympic swimming competitor from Rockhampton, Queensland. Diagnosed with muscular dystrophy at twelve months old, Liddell was initially told by doctors that she would never walk and would not live past her teens. Despite these predictions, she excelled in swimming and broke a world record by the age of 14. Liddell has competed in two Paralympic Games, winning a bronze medal at the 2000 Sydney Games in the Women's 4x50 m Freestyle 20 pts event. In 2010, she attempted to raise funds for Muscular Dystrophy Queensland to support research. Liddell is also an ambassador for Riding for the Disabled and has been involved in various community initiatives, including giving an opening speech at the 2011 North Queensland Athletics Carnival for Students with Disabilities. Additionally, she has been featured in a nude calendar of Australian Paralympians and had her image painted for an exhibition at the Customs House in Rockhampton. Liddell is a radio presenter for 4BC and is involved in mentoring programs for Australian Paralympians.

query: Tell me a bio of Winston Churchill.
answer:
Sir Winston Churchill was a British statesman, orator, and prolific writer. He is best known for his leadership as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom during World War II, where he played a crucial role in the Allied victory. Churchill's career was marked by significant achievements, including his return to the Commons in 1924 and his appointment as Prime Minister in 1940, following the fall of Neville Chamberlain's government. His oratory skills and unwavering resolve were instrumental in rallying the British people and the Allied forces.

Churchill was also a distinguished author and historian, with notable works such as "The World Crisis" (a history of World War I), "The Second World War," and "A History of the English-Speaking Peoples." His mastery of historical and biographical description earned him the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1953. Throughout his life, Churchill was the subject of numerous documentaries and films, including "The Gathering Storm" (2002) and "Churchill" (2017), which highlighted his pivotal role in history. His legacy is commemorated through various honors, including the establishment of the Winston Churchill Memorial Trust and the naming of the USS Winston S. Churchill, a destroyer of the United States Navy.

claims.claim: Sir Winston Churchill was appointed as Prime Minister in 1940, following the fall of Neville Chamberlain's government.
claims.label: Supported

safe_raw.response:
Let's analyze the given KNOWLEDGE step-by-step to determine if it supports the STATEMENT:

1. ** Appointment of Churchill as Prime Minister:**
   - "Winston Churchill became Britain's prime minister on 10 May 1940."
   - "In May 1940, he became prime minister, succeeding Neville Chamberlain."
   - "Winston Churchill became British prime minister on May 10, 1940. He succeeded Neville Chamberlain, who resigned after losing crucial support."
   - "Winston Churchill, First Lord of the Admiralty, is called to replace Neville Chamberlain as British prime minister following the latter's resignation."

   These points clearly indicate that Winston Churchill was appointed as Prime Minister in May 1940.

2. **Reason for Churchill's Appointment:**
   - "After British forces failed to prevent the German occupation of Norway in April 1940, Chamberlain lost the support of many members of his Conservative Party."
   - "On resigning, Chamberlain recommended Lord Halifax to the King as his successor."
   - "When Churchill became prime minister, he included Chamberlain in his War Cabinet."

   These points suggest that Neville Chamberlain's government fell due to the loss of support following the failure in Norway, and he recommended Lord Halifax as his successor. Despite this recommendation, Churchill was ultimately chosen to succeed Chamberlain.

3. **Summary of the Main Points:**
   - Winston Churchill was appointed as Prime Minister on May 10, 1940.
   - He succeeded Neville Chamberlain, who resigned after losing crucial support.
   - The loss of support was due to the failure to prevent the German occupation of Norway in April 1940.
   - Churchill was chosen to lead an all-party coalition government.

4. **Supporting Evidence:**
   - The KNOWLEDGE clearly states that Churchill became Prime Minister on May 10, 1940, following the resignation of Neville Chamberlain.
   - The reason for Chamberlain's resignation (loss of support) is also provided, which aligns with the concept of the "fall of Neville Chamberlain's government."

5. **Restatement of the STATEMENT:**
   - Sir Winston Churchill was appointed as Prime Minister in 1940, following the fall of Neville Chamberlain's government.

6. **Final Answer:**
   - The KNOWLEDGE strongly supports the STATEMENT, as it clearly indicates that Churchill was appointed as Prime Minister in May 1940 after Neville Chamberlain resigned due to the loss of support.

[Supported]

query: Tell me a bio of Milton Diamond.
answer: Milton Diamond (born March 6, 1934 in New York City) is a Professor Emeritus of anatomy and reproductive biology at the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa. He graduated from the City College of New York with a B.S. in biophysics in 1955 and later earned a Ph.D. in anatomy and psychology from the University of California, Berkeley between 1958 and 1962. After a three-year stint as an engineering officer in the Army, Diamond began his academic career at the University of Louisville, School of Medicine, where he also completed two years toward an M.D. and passed his Basic Medicine Boards. In 1967, he moved to Hawaii to join the John A. Burns School of Medicine at the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa, where he was appointed Professor of Anatomy and Reproductive Biology in 1971. From 1985 until his retirement in December 2009, he directed the Pacific Center for Sex and Society. Diamond is renowned for his research on the origins and development of sexual identity, and he has made significant contributions to the fields of transsexuality, intersexuality, and pornography. Despite retiring from teaching, he continues to engage in research and writing.

query: Tell me a bio of Michael Collins (astronaut).
answer:
Michael Collins (born October 31, 1930) is an American former astronaut and test pilot. He was selected as part of the third group of fourteen astronauts in 1963. Collins flew into space twice, first on Gemini 10, where he and Command Pilot John Young performed two rendezvous with different spacecraft and undertook two extra-vehicular activities (EVAs, also known as spacewalks). His second spaceflight was on Apollo 11, where he served as the Command Module Pilot, orbiting the Moon while Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin made the first manned landing on its surface. Collins is one of 24 people to have flown to the Moon and the fourth person, and third American, to perform an EVA.

After his astronaut career, Collins attained the rank of major general in the U.S. Air Force Reserves and retired in 1982. He was appointed director of the National Air and Space Museum in 1971, a position he held until 1978, and later became undersecretary of the Smithsonian Institution. Collins completed the Harvard Business School's Advanced Management Program in 1974 and served as Vice President of LTV Aerospace in Arlington, Virginia, from 1980. He has been inducted into the U.S. Astronaut Hall of Fame (1993), the National Aviation Hall of Fame (1985), and

query: Tell me a bio of Kim Casali.
answer: Kim Casali (9 September 1941 – 15 June 1997) was a New Zealand cartoonist best known for creating the syndicated cartoon feature "Love Is...," which she initially drew as love notes to her future husband in the late 1960s. Born Marilyn Judith Grove in Auckland, New Zealand, Casali left home at the age of nineteen to travel through Australia, Europe, and the United States. In 1967, she met and began a relationship with Roberto Alfredo Vincenzo Casali, an Italian businessman, in Los Angeles. The cartoons, which featured simple, expressive characters, quickly gained popularity, and by the 1970s, they were earning Casali £4–5 million annually. In 1975, Roberto was diagnosed with testicular cancer, and Casali spent the next year fighting for his treatment and concealing the severity of his condition from him. After Roberto's death, Casali became one of the first women to give birth to a child using her late husband's frozen sperm, a case that predated the Warnock Report and sparked legal discussions on posthumous reproduction. In the mid-1980s, Casali moved her family to New South Wales, Australia, where she bred Arabian horses. She later returned to England and settled in Leatherhead, Surrey.

query: Tell me a bio of Dana Awartani.
answer: Dana Awartani (born 1987) is a Palestinian-Saudi artist who was born and raised in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, where she continues to live and work. She earned a Bachelor's degree in Fine Art from Central Saint Martins, London, and later obtained a Master's in Traditional Arts from the Princes School, London, where she learned various traditional techniques, including stained glass, miniature painting, and gilding. Awartani's work is characterized by its integration of traditional Islamic art methods into contemporary contexts, often featuring intricate geometric patterns and detailed designs. Her art explores the relationship between geometry and nature, and she emphasizes the spiritual and sacred nature of Islamic art, viewing her work as a form of prayer and remembrance. She has stated that creating such art requires complete focus and patience, reflecting the principles of sabr (patience) and respect inherent in Islamic artistic practices.

query: Tell me a bio of Phil Vickery (rugby union).
answer: Philip John Vickery MBE DL (born 14 March 1976) is a former English rugby union tighthead prop and a member of the England squad. Born to Cornish parents in Barnstaple, Devon, England, Vickery began his rugby career at a young age, gaining his first National Representative honour at 16 when he was picked for the England Schools U16s group. He played for Gloucester Rugby for 11 years before signing a three-year deal with Wasps in 2006. Vickery made his England debut against Wales in 1998 and was part of the 2003 World Cup-winning squad, playing in all seven matches and captaining the side against Uruguay. He scored his first international try against Samoa in the same tournament. In 2001, he toured Australia with the British and Irish Lions, playing in all three tests. Vickery captained England during the 2007 Six Nations and the 2007 Rugby World Cup. He was selected for the 2008 Six Nations but missed the match against Italy due to injury. After a successful career, Vickery was forced to retire in 2010 due to neck injuries. query: Tell me a bio of Chris John (boxer).
answer:
Yohannes Christian "Chris" John is an Indonesian former professional boxer who competed from 1998 to 2013. Born on September 14, 1979, in Banjarnegara, John is the second son of Johan Tjahjadi and Maria Warsini. He began boxing at the age of five, inspired by his father, a former amateur boxer. John turned professional in 1997 and was trained by Sutan Rambing until 2004. He later trained with Craig Christian in Perth, Australia.

John held the WBA (Super) featherweight title from 2004 to 2013, making 18 successful title defenses, the second most in the division's history. Notable victories include a unanimous decision over Derrick Gainer in 2006 and a technical draw against Simpiwe Vetyeka in 2013, where he retained his title for the 18th time. He also fought Rocky Juarez in 2009, resulting in a unanimous draw, and called out other top contenders like Daniel Ponce de León and Juan Manuel Márquez. John was named Fighter of the Decade for the 2000s by the WBA in 2012. After retiring, he has appeared on TV shows, commercials, and runs his personal business with his wife.

query: Tell me a bio of Ra Jong-yil.
answer: Ra Jong-yil (born 1940) is a former South Korean diplomat and author known for his expertise on North Korean politics. He received his PhD from the University of Cambridge. Ra served as South Korea's ambassador to the United Kingdom from 2001 to 2003 and as ambassador to Japan from 2004 to 2007. In 2013, he published a book about Kang Min-chul, the only person who admitted involvement in an attempt to assassinate the South Korean president in 1983. Ra's 2016 book, "The Path Taken by Jang Song-thaek: A Rebellious Outsider," made significant claims that Kim Jong-il did not intend for his son, Kim Jong-un, to succeed him after his death. These works highlight Ra's deep engagement with the political dynamics of the Korean Peninsula.
